pages.title: Master Computer Science: specialisation Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
​Your programme

During your study at the University of Antwerp, you can live through a wide variety of applications of computer science. You will get first hand experience in a challenging, creative, dynamic and multi-disciplinary environment where you can contribute to the realisation of international projects.

A degree in Computer Science at the University of Antwerp corresponds with a competent professional with a scientific background. After obtaining the degree you will be able to:

  • adopt new technological developments in the respective disciplines within computer science
  • exploit these developments where applicable in their professional context
  • when required, make original contributions to the further development of the discipline

It is our ambition to offer a unique programme, which is based on recommendations from renowned scientific organisations such as the ACM, IEEE and SIAM. Our programme emphasises deep knowledge and sufficient flexibility and as such our graduates are highly demanded in both industrial as well as academic positions.

Your future

  • In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher…
  • Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
  • Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
  • A scientific career in academia, where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

pages.title: Study programme | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
2025-2026

In the Master's programme in Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence, you take a minimum of 120 credits: 18 credits of "Compulsory courses", 30 credits "Master's thesis", 54 credits of "Elective courses", of which at least 12 credits of electives in Software Engineering and at least 6 credits from both lists of electives of the other majors, and 18 credits of "Research Skills Development".

pages.title: Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
Your programme

During your study at the University of Antwerp, you can live through a wide variety of applications of computer science. You will get first hand experience in a challenging, creative, dynamic and multi-disciplinary environment where you can contribute to the realisation of international projects.

A degree in Computer Science at the University of Antwerp corresponds with a competent professional with a scientific background. After obtaining the degree you will be able to:

  • adopt new technological developments in the respective disciplines within computer science
  • exploit these developments where applicable in their professional context
  • when required, make original contributions to the further development of the discipline

It is our ambition to offer a unique programme, which is based on recommendations from renowned scientific organisations such as the ACM, IEEE and SIAM. Our programme emphasises deep knowledge and sufficient flexibility and as such our graduates are highly demanded in both industrial as well as academic positions.

Your future

  • In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher…
  • Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
  • Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
  • A scientific career in academia, where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

pages.markdown:
# Your programme

During your study at the University of Antwerp, you can live through a wide variety of applications of computer science. You will get first hand experience in a challenging, creative, dynamic and multi-disciplinary environment where you can contribute to the realisation of international projects.

A degree in Computer Science at the University of Antwerp corresponds with a competent professional with a scientific background. After obtaining the degree you will be able to:

- adopt new technological developments in the respective disciplines within computer science
- exploit these developments where applicable in their professional context
- when required, make original contributions to the further development of the discipline

It is our ambition to offer a unique programme, which is based on recommendations from renowned scientific organisations such as the ACM, IEEE and SIAM. Our programme emphasises deep knowledge and sufficient flexibility and as such our graduates are highly demanded in both industrial as well as academic positions.

# Your future

- In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher…
- Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
- Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
- A scientific career in academia, where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

pages.title: Programme info | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
• 120 ECTS-credits
  • Programme taught in English
  • Faculty of Science, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science
  • Campus Middelheim

What does the programme entail?

You can choose between three majors:

  • Computer Networks
  • Data Science
  • Software Engineering

The programme focuses on Research and Development. In contrast to the Dutch programme equivalent, there are no majors/minors such as Education or Management.

The two years are built out of 4 blocks:

  1. Master thesis "30 credits" (compulsory)
  2. Elective courses "30 credits"
  3. General competences "30 credits" (compulsory)
  4. Two research internships "15 credits each" (compulsory)

Download the programme structure

Are you eligible to start the programme?

More information on admission and enrollment can be found on this page.​

Research in your programme

The common theme of the master programme is modelling as applied in all the subdisciplines of computer science. This comprises:

  • modelling and simulation of scientific phenomena (e.g. the human genome project, weather prediction)
  • interactions between parts of complex machines (e.g. automotive, medical devices)
  • understanding the foundations of computer science (e.g. search engines, programming languages, network protocols)

As in all scientific disciplines such models allow us to understand and control our environment, as such allowing us to make predictions about what will happen in critical situations.

The master programme culminates in the master's thesis. The aim of this thesis is for you to show that you are able to (under supervision of a promoter) explore independently a complex subject in a scientific manner and write down the acquired insight into a coherent text.

Practice in your programme

A computer scientist with academic training should be capable of applying the knowledge and skills acquired through the programme in concrete day-to-day situations. Consequently there is ample room for practical work and - not surprisingly - group work. Former graduates informed us that independence and maturity are strengths of programme.

Besides project work, there is also time for experiments and exercises in the computer lab. We have the necessary technical infrastructure and ensure that it keeps pace with the natural evolution in the field.

Laptop profile

We expect students to bring a regular laptop running Linux and/or Windows (MacOS often suffices, but support may be limited). Operating system: Modern medium range GPU. University computing servers will be used for demanding computations.

[Download the programme structure](https://medialibrary.uantwerpen.be/oldcontent/container1991/files/MCS ProgrStruct2016-2017 OC20150513.pdf)

# Are you eligible to start the programme?

More information on admission and enrollment can be found on [this page.](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/programmes/all-programmes/master-data-science/admission-and-enrolment/)

# Research in your programme

The common theme of the master programme is modelling as applied in all the subdisciplines of computer science. This comprises:

- modelling and simulation of scientific phenomena (e.g. the human genome project, weather prediction)
- interactions between parts of complex machines (e.g. automotive, medical devices)
- understanding the foundations of computer science (e.g. search engines, programming languages, network protocols)

As in all scientific disciplines such models allow us to understand and control our environment, as such allowing us to make predictions about what will happen in critical situations.

The master programme culminates in the master's thesis. The aim of this thesis is for you to show that you are able to (under supervision of a promoter) explore independently a complex subject in a scientific manner and write down the acquired insight into a coherent text.

# Practice in your programme

A computer scientist with academic training should be capable of applying the knowledge and skills acquired through the programme in concrete day-to-day situations. Consequently there is ample room for practical work and - not surprisingly - group work. Former graduates informed us that independence and maturity are strengths of programme.

Besides project work, there is also time for experiments and exercises in the computer lab. We have the necessary technical infrastructure and ensure that it keeps pace with the natural evolution in the field.

# Laptop profile

We expect students to bring a regular laptop running Linux and/or Windows (MacOS often suffices, but support may be limited). Operating system: Modern medium range GPU. University computing servers will be used for demanding computations.

pages.title: Job opportunities | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
The choice is yours

Once you obtained a degree in computer science you are almost certain of various job opportunities and interesting career perspectives. It will be much less a matter whether you will find a job, but more whether you will find a job that matches your interests.

All major challenges in science and technology in the current century are multidisciplinary in nature; i.e. several disciplines must bond together to create inspiring environments. Computer scientists play a pivotal role: they collect and organise the data to ensure that the numerous software systems, networks, algorithms can exchange information seamlessly. For instance at the CERN lab, computer scientists mediate between physicists and engineers. Similarly in the human genome project, computer scientists ensure that doctors and biochemists can exchange the complex information encoded in DNA strings.

The modern economy with its emphasis on global competition and sustainable development poses interesting challenges for computer scientists. New industrial systems, implementation and optimisation of specialised software, networks with higher performance and security, faster computation cycles — these all present opportunities for young computer scientists.

Career opportunities

Just a sample of career opportunities.

  • In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher...
  • Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
  • Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
  • A scientific career in academia where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

On top of these sectors there are a number of application areas with great economic significance and technological value where computer scientists can make a difference: alternative energy sources, high performance computing, nanotechnology, biotechnology, wireless communication, self healing materials, superconductors, semi-conductors...

2025-2026

pages.title: Programme info | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
• 120 ECTS-credits
  • Programme taught in English
  • Faculty of Science, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science
  • Campus Middelheim

What does the programme entail?

You can choose between three majors:

  • Computer Networks
  • Data Science
  • Software Engineering

The programme focuses on Research and Development. In contrast to the Dutch programme equivalent, there are no majors/minors such as Education or Management.

The two years are built out of 4 blocks:

  1. Master thesis "30 credits" (compulsory)
  2. Elective courses "30 credits"
  3. General competences "30 credits" (compulsory)
  4. Two research internships "15 credits each" (compulsory)

Download the programme structure

Are you eligible to start the programme?

More information on admission and enrollment can be found on this page.​

Research in your programme

The common theme of the master programme is modelling as applied in all the subdisciplines of computer science. This comprises:

  • modelling and simulation of scientific phenomena (e.g. the human genome project, weather prediction)
  • interactions between parts of complex machines (e.g. automotive, medical devices)
  • understanding the foundations of computer science (e.g. search engines, programming languages, network protocols)

As in all scientific disciplines such models allow us to understand and control our environment, as such allowing us to make predictions about what will happen in critical situations.

The master programme culminates in the master's thesis. The aim of this thesis is for you to show that you are able to (under supervision of a promoter) explore independently a complex subject in a scientific manner and write down the acquired insight into a coherent text.

Practice in your programme

A computer scientist with academic training should be capable of applying the knowledge and skills acquired through the programme in concrete day-to-day situations. Consequently there is ample room for practical work and - not surprisingly - group work. Former graduates informed us that independence and maturity are strengths of programme.

Besides project work, there is also time for experiments and exercises in the computer lab. We have the necessary technical infrastructure and ensure that it keeps pace with the natural evolution in the field.

Laptop profile

We expect students to bring a regular laptop running Linux and/or Windows (MacOS often suffices, but support may be limited). Operating system: Modern medium range GPU. University computing servers will be used for demanding computations.

pages.title: Job opportunities | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
The choice is yours

Once you obtained a degree in computer science you are almost certain of various job opportunities and interesting career perspectives. It will be much less a matter whether you will find a job, but more whether you will find a job that matches your interests.

All major challenges in science and technology in the current century are multidisciplinary in nature; i.e. several disciplines must bond together to create inspiring environments. Computer scientists play a pivotal role: they collect and organise the data to ensure that the numerous software systems, networks, algorithms can exchange information seamlessly. For instance at the CERN lab, computer scientists mediate between physicists and engineers. Similarly in the human genome project, computer scientists ensure that doctors and biochemists can exchange the complex information encoded in DNA strings.

The modern economy with its emphasis on global competition and sustainable development poses interesting challenges for computer scientists. New industrial systems, implementation and optimisation of specialised software, networks with higher performance and security, faster computation cycles — these all present opportunities for young computer scientists.

Career opportunities

Just a sample of career opportunities.

  • In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher...
  • Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
  • Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
  • A scientific career in academia where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

On top of these sectors there are a number of application areas with great economic significance and technological value where computer scientists can make a difference: alternative energy sources, high performance computing, nanotechnology, biotechnology, wireless communication, self healing materials, superconductors, semi-conductors...

  • A scientific career in academia where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

On top of these sectors there are a number of application areas with great economic significance and technological value where computer scientists can make a difference: alternative energy sources, high performance computing, nanotechnology, biotechnology, wireless communication, self healing materials, superconductors, semi-conductors...
pages.markdown:
# The choice is yours

Once you obtained a degree in computer science you are almost certain of various job opportunities and interesting career perspectives. It will be much less a matter whether you will find a job, but more whether you will find a job that matches your interests.

All major challenges in science and technology in the current century are multidisciplinary in nature; i.e. several disciplines must bond together to create inspiring environments. Computer scientists play a pivotal role: they collect and organise the data to ensure that the numerous software systems, networks, algorithms can exchange information seamlessly. For instance at the CERN lab, computer scientists mediate between physicists and engineers. Similarly in the human genome project, computer scientists ensure that doctors and biochemists can exchange the complex information encoded in DNA strings.

The modern economy with its emphasis on global competition and sustainable development poses interesting challenges for computer scientists. New industrial systems, implementation and optimisation of specialised software, networks with higher performance and security, faster computation cycles — these all present opportunities for young computer scientists.

# Career opportunities

Just a sample of career opportunities.

- In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher...
- Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
- Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
- A scientific career in academia where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

On top of these sectors there are a number of application areas with great economic significance and technological value where computer scientists can make a difference: alternative energy sources, high performance computing, nanotechnology, biotechnology, wireless communication, self healing materials, superconductors, semi-conductors...

pages.title: Programme info | Master of Computer Science: Computer Networks | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
• 120 ECTS-credits
  • Programme taught in English
  • Faculty of Science, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science
  • Campus Middelheim

What does the programme entail?

You can choose between three majors:

  • Computer Networks
  • Data Science
  • Software Engineering

The programme focuses on Research and Development. In contrast to the Dutch programme equivalent, there are no majors/minors such as Education or Management.

The two years are built out of 4 blocks:

  1. Master thesis "30 credits" (compulsory)
  2. Elective courses "30 credits"
  3. General competences "30 credits" (compulsory)
  4. Two research internships "15 credits each" (compulsory)

Download the programme structure

Are you eligible to start the programme?

More information on admission and enrollment can be found on this page.

Research in your programme

The common theme of the master programme is modelling as applied in all the subdisciplines of computer science. This comprises:

  • modelling and simulation of scientific phenomena (e.g. the human genome project, weather prediction)
  • interactions between parts of complex machines (e.g. automotive, medical devices)
  • understanding the foundations of computer science (e.g. search engines, programming languages, network protocols)

As in all scientific disciplines such models allow us to understand and control our environment, as such allowing us to make predictions about what will happen in critical situations.

The master programme culminates in the master's thesis. The aim of this thesis is for you to show that you are able to (under supervision of a promoter) explore independently a complex subject in a scientific manner and write down the acquired insight into a coherent text.

Practice in your programme

A computer scientist with academic training should be capable of applying the knowledge and skills acquired through the programme in concrete day-to-day situations. Consequently there is ample room for practical work and - not surprisingly - group work. Former graduates informed us that independence and maturity are strengths of programme.

Besides project work, there is also time for experiments and exercises in the computer lab. We have the necessary technical infrastructure and ensure that it keeps pace with the natural evolution in the field.

Laptop profile

We expect students to bring a regular laptop running Linux and/or Windows (MacOS often suffices, but support may be limited). Operating system: Modern medium range GPU. University computing servers will be used for demanding computations.

pages.title: Job opportunities | Master of Computer Science: Computer Networks | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
The choice is yours

Once you obtained a degree in computer science you are almost certain of various job opportunities and interesting career perspectives. It will be much less a matter whether you will find a job, but more whether you will find a job that matches your interests.

All major challenges in science and technology in the current century are multidisciplinary in nature; i.e. several disciplines must bond together to create inspiring environments. Computer scientists play a pivotal role: they collect and organise the data to ensure that the numerous software systems, networks, algorithms can exchange information seamlessly. For instance at the CERN lab, computer scientists mediate between physicists and engineers. Similarly in the human genome project, computer scientists ensure that doctors and biochemists can exchange the complex information encoded in DNA strings.

The modern economy with its emphasis on global competition and sustainable development poses interesting challenges for computer scientists. New industrial systems, implementation and optimisation of specialised software, networks with higher performance and security, faster computation cycles — these all present opportunities for young computer scientists.

Career opportunities

Just a sample of career opportunities.

  • In a corporate organisation you can work as a technology consultant, software designer, system developer, software architect, software analyst, web designer and developer, project leader, industrial researcher...
  • Many computer scientists end up in the Research and Development departments of industrial organisations (both large and small) to address technological challenges of all kinds.
  • Your background allows you to deal with fast changing environments; which is a necessary prerequisite for project management positions.
  • A scientific career in academia where you think about in depth problems of computer science. Together with other scientists and companies you work inside European or international projects on a variety of disciplines.

On top of these sectors there are a number of application areas with great economic significance and technological value where computer scientists can make a difference: alternative energy sources, high performance computing, nanotechnology, biotechnology, wireless communication, self healing materials, superconductors, semi-conductors...

pages.title: Learning outcomes | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
1. Analysis for large-scale informatics projects. Identifying tasks that qualify for automation, understanding underlying business processes, determining the corresponding consumer needs. This requires the necessary knowledge for fluent communication with people working in other disciplines.

2. Design of large-scale informatics systems. Abstraction and decomposition of the specific problem to arrive at a feasible solution. Identifying components that could contribute to a solution (e.g. software library, type of network, kind of database). Documenting the chosen solutions on different levels of abstraction.

3. Restructuring existing informatics systems. Identifying problematic components, selecting solution strategies, implementing the necessary adjustments without compromising the existing system’s functioning.

4. Quality control. Planning the necessary check-ups while carrying out informatics projects in order to attain the previously specified quality standards (as to reliability, practicality of maintenance, safety …). Drawing lessons from informatics projects that have been carried out, in order to optimize quality norms wherever necessary.

5. Selecting techniques, methods, languages, architectures, taking into account their inherent limitations and the fact that information on concrete solutions is usually commercially coloured. Making strategic decisions in this respect: e.g. how do we protect our network? What type of database? What role for formal specifications? Scientific motivation of the decisions that have been made.

6. Reporting the progress and status of computer science projects to clients (meaning non-information scientists) and experts from other fields, both orally and in writing.

7. Leading a team of information scientists, including (a) assessment of the necessary means (time, budget, instruments, manpower, competences), (b) division of tasks on the basis of technical competences, (c) time planning of the tasks, (d) following and adjusting the planning.

8. Society. Has a sense of responsibility. Makes connections between social trends and developments in computer science and considers the consequences of actions.

9. Profundity. Has theoretical and practical experiences with instruments, techniques and methods used in scientific research of a specific subfield of information sciences.

10. Research and development in a product-oriented environment. This means (a) being able to set up experiments to determine if certain techniques are usable for a company; (b) recognising opportunities to improve products and production processes; (c) estimate costs/benefits of new techniques and methods; (d) using new techniques to gain a strategic advantage over the competition.

11. Fundamental research. Have the necessary skills needed to independently start scientific research, for instance in order to obtain a PhD. This means (a) having insight in current research questions within a subfield of Information Sciences; (b) being able to see the implications of recent research results; (c) being able to independently apply publicised results or techniques in a new context.

12. Data Science. Recognize a data science problem and select the best solution strategy, such as data mining and machine learning techniques for data analysis (e.g. decision trees, association rules, bayesian networks) and data management techniques for (non) distributed storage, data management and data search. Apply data science techniques to large and complex databases and interpret the results sensibly. Follow new evolutions in scientific research in data science, appropriate it and contribute to it.

13. Artificial Intelligence. Have extensive knowledge of and expertise in the application of artificial intelligence techniques, such as self learning systems and artificial neural networks. Recognize situations in which these techniques can be applied (e.g. image processing), implement and correctly evaluate a solution. Have a broad theoretical basis that enables the follow-up and critical evaluation of scientifc research in artificial intelligence.

14. Data modelling and management. Select the best database model and the optimal search techniques for data intensive applications. Use recent technology (e.g. distributed and heterogenous databases) where necessary. Have extensive knowledge of the foundations of databases that can be used in the development of new techniques and applications.
pages.html_clean:
1. Analysis for large-scale informatics projects. Identifying tasks that qualify for automation, understanding underlying business processes, determining the corresponding consumer needs. This requires the necessary knowledge for fluent communication with people working in other disciplines.

2. Design of large-scale informatics systems. Abstraction and decomposition of the specific problem to arrive at a feasible solution. Identifying components that could contribute to a solution (e.g. software library, type of network, kind of database). Documenting the chosen solutions on different levels of abstraction.

3. Restructuring existing informatics systems. Identifying problematic components, selecting solution strategies, implementing the necessary adjustments without compromising the existing system’s functioning.

4. Quality control. Planning the necessary check-ups while carrying out informatics projects in order to attain the previously specified quality standards (as to reliability, practicality of maintenance, safety …). Drawing lessons from informatics projects that have been carried out, in order to optimize quality norms wherever necessary.

5. Selecting techniques, methods, languages, architectures, taking into account their inherent limitations and the fact that information on concrete solutions is usually commercially coloured. Making strategic decisions in this respect: e.g. how do we protect our network? What type of database? What role for formal specifications? Scientific motivation of the decisions that have been made.

6. Reporting the progress and status of computer science projects to clients (meaning non-information scientists) and experts from other fields, both orally and in writing.

7. Leading a team of information scientists, including (a) assessment of the necessary means (time, budget, instruments, manpower, competences), (b) division of tasks on the basis of technical competences, (c) time planning of the tasks, (d) following and adjusting the planning.

8. Society. Has a sense of responsibility. Makes connections between social trends and developments in computer science and considers the consequences of actions.

9. Profundity. Has theoretical and practical experiences with instruments, techniques and methods used in scientific research of a specific subfield of information sciences.

10. Research and development in a product-oriented environment. This means (a) being able to set up experiments to determine if certain techniques are usable for a company; (b) recognising opportunities to improve products and production processes; (c) estimate costs/benefits of new techniques and methods; (d) using new techniques to gain a strategic advantage over the competition.

11. Fundamental research. Have the necessary skills needed to independently start scientific research, for instance in order to obtain a PhD. This means (a) having insight in current research questions within a subfield of Information Sciences; (b) being able to see the implications of recent research results; (c) being able to independently apply publicised results or techniques in a new context.

12. Data Science. Recognize a data science problem and select the best solution strategy, such as data mining and machine learning techniques for data analysis (e.g. decision trees, association rules, bayesian networks) and data management techniques for (non) distributed storage, data management and data search. Apply data science techniques to large and complex databases and interpret the results sensibly. Follow new evolutions in scientific research in data science, appropriate it and contribute to it.

13. Artificial Intelligence. Have extensive knowledge of and expertise in the application of artificial intelligence techniques, such as self learning systems and artificial neural networks. Recognize situations in which these techniques can be applied (e.g. image processing), implement and correctly evaluate a solution. Have a broad theoretical basis that enables the follow-up and critical evaluation of scientifc research in artificial intelligence.

14. Data modelling and management. Select the best database model and the optimal search techniques for data intensive applications. Use recent technology (e.g. distributed and heterogenous databases) where necessary. Have extensive knowledge of the foundations of databases that can be used in the development of new techniques and applications.

pages.title: Quality assurance | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
At the University of Antwerp we ensure the quality of our programmes. Every programme goes through a six-year quality assurance cycle.

In year three, we review the quality assurance of the programme during the internal process monitoring and control. In autumn 2019 this was done for the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science.

A peer review in year six concludes the cycle. The study programme conducts a self-reflection and has  discussions with internal and external experts and with an independent student.

On 13-14 December 2023 the peer review team visited the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science and decided to confirm its confidence in the programme.

Conclusions of the peer review team

The programme offers broad and well-balanced fundamentals in the bachelor's to be well prepared for the three specialisations in the master's, where the programme is strong in terms of research. Frequent use is made of group work and project work, where independent thinking and problem-solving is learned step by step. The programme plans more effective use of peer feedback and peer evaluation according to needs. The review team found that students (and graduates) are very satisfied with the programme since there are short lines of communication with teachers, concerns of students are taken into account and the developed hard and soft skills are a good preparation for the professional field.

To better match the large influx of Belgian and international students, in the coming period the programme will, among other things, make the structure of the programme and its unique profile clearer in communication. Possible obstacles to mapping out one's own path in the wide range of choices in the master's programme will be investigated and, if possible, remedied.

In order to get better acquainted with companies, job events will be organised and the possibility of a company internship will be looked into. More opportunities for international experiences will also be pursued.

​Read the entire public report​

Facts and figures

The website 'opleiding in cijfers' gives you more detailed information about alle programmes in Flemish university colleges and universities.

pages.title: Admission requirements | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
If you have a bachelor degree from the Benelux

Direct admission:

  • academic bachelor of Information Sciences
  • academic bachelor of Computer Science
  • academic bachelor of Engineering Sciences: Computer Science

If you have a bachelor degree from outside the Benelux

There are several criteria applicants with an international previous education must meet: academic requirements, programme specific requirements and English-language proficiency requirements.

1.      Academic admission requirements

You can apply for our master's programme if your bachelor's degree is deemed comparable to the University of Antwerp's bachelor's degree in Computer Science.  If you have a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science or Artificial Intelligence, or in a Computer Science-related programme from a foreign university with a level similar to Belgian universities, you are eligible to apply.

2.      Programme specific admission requirements

The Admission Board will also the assess whether your degree and background are sufficiently related to the level and content of our own BSc degree in Computer Science. 

Given the wide variety of computer science and informatics degrees, the Board of Admissions checks in particular:

  • Software engineering background: is the candidate familiar with object-oriented software development? Does the program include software-engineering courses with a significant software development component? Will the candidate be able to independently program software? Programs in which computer science was studied as a minor often lack in this respect.
  • Is there a solid mathematics background? Does the curriculum include advanced courses on discrete mathematics, linear algebra, calculus, and statistics? Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more application-oriented studies.
  • Does the curriculum cover theoretical computer science subjects? This includes the study of data structures, algorithm analysis, and computational complexity. Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more IT management, Informatics-like or Electrical Engineering-oriented bachelor’s programs.

How to demonstrate that you meet the programme specific requirements

You are required to indicate how you meet these programme specific admission requirements through our prescreening form.

This prescreening form is an essential element in this assessment, for the Board of Admissions and for yourself. Make sure to complete it rigorously and honestly. Based on your transcripts and the pre-screening form, the Board of Admissions checks if there is a good match of the topics covered by your Bachelor's program and our Bachelor's in Computer Science. The subjects are grouped into "Computer skills", "math skills", "theoretical computer science", "databases", "software engineering", and "computer networks". The board’s flexibility on which of these groups are not covered by courses you have taken is very limited. Also, self-study is only taken into account as reinforcement in a group where insufficiently many courses are listed, not as a replacement.

3.      Language requirements

The programme is taught in English and an academic level of proficiency in this language is imperative.

Candidates with a bachelor degree from universities outside Flanders are required to demonstrate their English language skills in by submitting one of the language certificates listed here.

pages.title: Application | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
Bachelor's degree from the Benelux and you do not have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you don’t need to proceed via Mobility Online.

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that does not grant direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you will have to apply for permission from the faculty. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree from the Benelux but you have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission BUT you are required to have a visa, you have to submit an online application via Mobility Online. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree outside Benelux?

If you obtained a bachelor's or master's degree from a higher education institution OUTSIDE Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg, you need to submit an online application via Mobility Online, before you can enrol. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

# Bachelor's degree from the Benelux and you do not have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you don’t need to proceed via Mobility Online.

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that does not grant direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you will have to apply for [permission](https://studhelp.uantwerpen.be/wetenschappen/knowledgebase.php?article=121) from the faculty. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

# Bachelor's degree from the Benelux but you have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission BUT you are required to have a visa, you have to submit an [online application](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master/) via Mobility Online. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

# Bachelor's degree outside Benelux?

If you obtained a bachelor's or master's degree from a higher education institution OUTSIDE Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg, you need to submit an [online application](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master/) via Mobility Online, before you can enrol. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

pages.title: Tuition fees, scholarships and costs | Master of Computer Science: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
Tuition fees

Tuition fees are subject to yearly revision. www.uantwerpen.be/en/education/admission-and-enrolment/enrolment/tuition-fees/.

Scholarships

Scholarships

The University of Antwerp directly participates in the selection process of certain scholarship programmes (Scholarships with UAntwerp participation). In addition students can also check if they are eligible for external funding opportunities (External scholarships).

Do check with the Belgian embassy in your country whether they have any funding options.

Note that the tuition fee for most of UAntwerp's study programmes is reasonable when compared internationally.

Tuition fee reduction

The Faculty of Science at the University of Antwerp grants a limited number of tuition fee reductions to international students with demonstrated academic excellence who register for the first time one of our master programmes listed below. The fee reduction is only applicable to students who would otherwise need to pay the increased rate of tuition fees.

To be eligible for a fee reduction the applicant needs to fulfil at least the following criteria:  

  • does not yet have a master degree
  • has no other scholarship
  • has a clear and profound motivation
  • and has a high standard of academic performance 

Only applicants who are academically admitted, can apply for the tuition fee reduction.  

The application deadline is 31 August. The applicant will be informed of the decision within 3 weeks after the application deadline. There will be no further communication on the decision.

​Apply for a tuition fee reduction

Cost of living

If you want to get a full overview of all the costs you can expect, from housing and accommodation to books and lifestyle, you can consult this page.​

Scholarships

The University of Antwerp directly participates in the selection process of certain scholarship programmes ([Scholarships with UAntwerp participation](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/scholarships/scholarships-with-uantwerp-participation/)). In addition students can also check if they are eligible for external funding opportunities ([External scholarships](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/scholarships/external-scholarships/)).

Do check with the Belgian embassy in your country whether they have any funding options.

Note that the [tuition fee](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/enrolment/tuition-fees/) for most of UAntwerp's study programmes is reasonable when compared internationally.

Tuition fee reduction

The Faculty of Science at the University of Antwerp grants a limited number of tuition fee reductions to international students with demonstrated academic excellence who register for the first time one of our master programmes listed below. The fee reduction is only applicable to students who would otherwise need to pay the increased rate of [tuition fees](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/enrolment/tuition-fees/tuition-fees-2024-2025/).

To be eligible for a fee reduction the applicant needs to fulfil at least the following criteria:

- does not yet have a master degree
- has no other scholarship
- has a clear and profound motivation
- and has a high standard of academic performance

Only applicants who are [academically admitted](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master/), can apply for the tuition fee reduction.

The application deadline is 31 August. The applicant will be informed of the decision within 3 weeks after the application deadline. There will be no further communication on the decision.

[Apply for a tuition fee reduction](https://eur01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.uantwerpen.be%2Fen%2Ffacwet%2Ftuition-fee-reduction%2F&data=04%7C01%7Csarah.verberckmoes%40uantwerpen.be%7C7d009cace2764066188a08d920f11e12%7C792e08fb2d544a8eaf72202548136ef6%7C0%7C0%7C637577042221817362%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Epb2R%2BESX7VH6c10qYQ0B4t62UIjYuvOieRutu%2Br2u8%3D&reserved=0)

# Cost of living

If you want to get a full overview of all the costs you can expect, from housing and accommodation to books and lifestyle, you can consult [this page.](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/life-in-antwerp/budget-social-facilities/cost-of-studying/)

pages.title: Learning outcomes | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
1. Analysis for large-scale informatics projects. Identifying tasks that qualify for automation, understanding underlying business processes, determining the corresponding consumer needs. This requires the necessary knowledge for fluent communication with people working in other disciplines.

2. Design of large-scale informatics systems. Abstraction and decomposition of the specific problem to arrive at a feasible solution. Identifying components that could contribute to a solution (e.g. software library, type of network, kind of database). Documenting the chosen solutions on different levels of abstraction.

3. Restructuring existing informatics systems. Identifying problematic components, selecting solution strategies, implementing the necessary adjustments without compromising the existing system’s functioning.

4. Quality control. Planning the necessary check-ups while carrying out informatics projects in order to attain the previously specified quality standards (as to reliability, practicality of maintenance, safety …). Drawing lessons from informatics projects that have been carried out, in order to optimize quality norms wherever necessary.

5. Selecting techniques, methods, languages, architectures, taking into account their inherent limitations and the fact that information on concrete solutions is usually commercially coloured. Making strategic decisions in this respect: e.g. how do we protect our network? What type of database? What role for formal specifications? Scientific motivation of the decisions that have been made.

6. Reporting the progress and status of computer science projects to clients (meaning non-information scientists) and experts from other fields, both orally and in writing.

7. Leading a team of information scientists, including (a) assessment of the necessary means (time, budget, instruments, manpower, competences), (b) division of tasks on the basis of technical competences, (c) time planning of the tasks, (d) following and adjusting the planning.

8. Society. Has a sense of responsibility. Makes connections between social trends and developments in computer science and considers the consequences of actions.

9. Profundity. Has theoretical and practical experiences with instruments, techniques and methods used in scientific research of a specific subfield of information sciences.

10. Research and development in a product-oriented environment. This means (a) being able to set up experiments to determine if certain techniques are usable for a company; (b) recognising opportunities to improve products and production processes; (c) estimate costs/benefits of new techniques and methods; (d) using new techniques to gain a strategic advantage over the competition.

11. Fundamental research. Have the necessary skills needed to independently start scientific research, for instance in order to obtain a PhD. This means (a) having insight in current research questions within a subfield of Information Sciences; (b) being able to see the implications of recent research results; (c) being able to independently apply publicised results or techniques in a new context.

12. Modeling. Using models to descibe and quantify all aspect of a computer system. Having an overview of the most common modeling formalisms and their main characteristics (pro and cons, specific field of application, …). Having applied some of them in both the design of a new system and the analysis or improvement of an existing system. Using these models for communication with people active in other disciplines.

13. Tools. Having experience with the available tools for analysis, verification, simulation and transformation of software systems. Having insight in their internal mechanisms, which transpires in the successful combination, adaptation or building of such tools (e.g. making additions to open-source instruments).

pages.title: Quality assurance | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
At the University of Antwerp we ensure the quality of our programmes. Every programme goes through a six-year quality assurance cycle.

In year three, we review the quality assurance of the programme during the internal process monitoring and control. In autumn 2019 this was done for the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science.

A peer review in year six concludes the cycle. The study programme conducts a self-reflection and has  discussions with internal and external experts and with an independent student.

On 13-14 December 2023 the peer review team visited the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science and decided to confirm its confidence in the programme.

Conclusions of the peer review team

The programme offers broad and well-balanced fundamentals in the bachelor's to be well prepared for the three specialisations in the master's, where the programme is strong in terms of research. Frequent use is made of group work and project work, where independent thinking and problem-solving is learned step by step. The programme plans more effective use of peer feedback and peer evaluation according to needs. The review team found that students (and graduates) are very satisfied with the programme since there are short lines of communication with teachers, concerns of students are taken into account and the developed hard and soft skills are a good preparation for the professional field.

To better match the large influx of Belgian and international students, in the coming period the programme will, among other things, make the structure of the programme and its unique profile clearer in communication. Possible obstacles to mapping out one's own path in the wide range of choices in the master's programme will be investigated and, if possible, remedied.

In order to get better acquainted with companies, job events will be organised and the possibility of a company internship will be looked into. More opportunities for international experiences will also be pursued.

​Read the entire public report​

Facts and figures

The website 'opleiding in cijfers' gives you more detailed information about alle programmes in Flemish university colleges and universities.

pages.title: Admission requirements | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
If you have a bachelor degree from the Benelux

Direct admission:

  • academic bachelor of Information Sciences
  • academic bachelor of Computer Science
  • academic bachelor of Engineering Sciences: Computer Science

If you have a bachelor degree from outside the Benelux

There are several criteria applicants with an international previous education must meet: academic requirements, programme specific requirements and English-language proficiency requirements.

1.      Academic admission requirements

You can apply for our master's programme if your bachelor's degree is deemed comparable to the University of Antwerp's bachelor's degree in Computer Science.  If you have a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science or Artificial Intelligence, or in a Computer Science-related programme from a foreign university with a level similar to Belgian universities, you are eligible to apply.

2.      Programme specific admission requirements

The Admission Board will also the assess whether your degree and background are sufficiently related to the level and content of our own BSc degree in Computer Science. 

Given the wide variety of computer science and informatics degrees, the Board of Admissions checks in particular:

  • Software engineering background: is the candidate familiar with object-oriented software development? Does the program include software-engineering courses with a significant software development component? Will the candidate be able to independently program software? Programs in which computer science was studied as a minor often lack in this respect.
  • Is there a solid mathematics background? Does the curriculum include advanced courses on discrete mathematics, linear algebra, calculus, and statistics? Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more application-oriented studies.
  • Does the curriculum cover theoretical computer science subjects? This includes the study of data structures, algorithm analysis, and computational complexity. Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more IT management, Informatics-like or Electrical Engineering-oriented bachelor’s programs.

How to demonstrate that you meet the programme specific requirements

You are required to indicate how you meet these programme specific admission requirements through our prescreening form.

This prescreening form is an essential element in this assessment, for the Board of Admissions and for yourself. Make sure to complete it rigorously and honestly. Based on your transcripts and the pre-screening form, the Board of Admissions checks if there is a good match of the topics covered by your Bachelor's program and our Bachelor's in Computer Science. The subjects are grouped into "Computer skills", "math skills", "theoretical computer science", "databases", "software engineering", and "computer networks". The board’s flexibility on which of these groups are not covered by courses you have taken is very limited. Also, self-study is only taken into account as reinforcement in a group where insufficiently many courses are listed, not as a replacement.

3.      Language requirements

The programme is taught in English and an academic level of proficiency in this language is imperative.

Candidates with a bachelor degree from universities outside Flanders are required to demonstrate their English language skills in by submitting one of the language certificates listed here.

pages.title: Application | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
Bachelor's degree from the Benelux and you do not have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you don’t need to proceed via Mobility Online.

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that does not grant direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you will have to apply for permission from the faculty. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree from the Benelux but you have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission BUT you are required to have a visa, you have to submit an online application via Mobility Online. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree outside Benelux?

If you obtained a bachelor's or master's degree from a higher education institution OUTSIDE Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg, you need to submit an online application via Mobility Online, before you can enrol. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that does not grant direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you will have to apply for [permission](https://studhelp.uantwerpen.be/wetenschappen/knowledgebase.php?article=121) from the faculty. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

# Bachelor's degree from the Benelux but you have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission BUT you are required to have a visa, you have to submit an [online application](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master/) via Mobility Online. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

# Bachelor's degree outside Benelux?

If you obtained a bachelor's or master's degree from a higher education institution OUTSIDE Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg, you need to submit an [online application](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master/) via Mobility Online, before you can enrol. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.

pages.title: Tuition fees, scholarships and costs | Master of Computer Science: Software Engineering | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
Tuition fees

Tuition fees are subject to yearly revision. www.uantwerpen.be/en/education/admission-and-enrolment/enrolment/tuition-fees/.

Scholarships

Scholarships

The University of Antwerp directly participates in the selection process of certain scholarship programmes (Scholarships with UAntwerp participation). In addition students can also check if they are eligible for external funding opportunities (External scholarships).

Do check with the Belgian embassy in your country whether they have any funding options.

Note that the tuition fee for most of UAntwerp's study programmes is reasonable when compared internationally.

Tuition fee reduction

The Faculty of Science at the University of Antwerp grants a limited number of tuition fee reductions to international students with demonstrated academic excellence who register for the first time one of our master programmes listed below. The fee reduction is only applicable to students who would otherwise need to pay the increased rate of tuition fees.

To be eligible for a fee reduction the applicant needs to fulfil at least the following criteria:  

  • does not yet have a master degree
  • has no other scholarship
  • has a clear and profound motivation
  • and has a high standard of academic performance 

Only applicants who are academically admitted, can apply for the tuition fee reduction.  

The application deadline is 31 August. The applicant will be informed of the decision within 3 weeks after the application deadline. There will be no further communication on the decision.

​Apply for a tuition fee reduction

Cost of living

If you want to get a full overview of all the costs you can expect, from housing and accommodation to books and lifestyle, you can consult this page.​

pages.title: Learning outcomes | Master of Computer Science: Computer Networks | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
1. Analysis for large-scale informatics projects. Identifying tasks that qualify for automation, understanding underlying business processes, determining the corresponding consumer needs. This requires the necessary knowledge for fluent communication with people working in other disciplines.

2. Design of large-scale informatics systems. Abstraction and decomposition of the specific problem to arrive at a feasible solution. Identifying components that could contribute to a solution (e.g. software library, type of network, kind of database). Documenting the chosen solutions on different levels of abstraction.

3. Restructuring existing informatics systems. Identifying problematic components, selecting solution strategies, implementing the necessary adjustments without compromising the existing system’s functioning.

4. Quality control. Planning the necessary check-ups while carrying out informatics projects in order to attain the previously specified quality standards (as to reliability, practicality of maintenance, safety …). Drawing lessons from informatics projects that have been carried out, in order to optimize quality norms wherever necessary.

5. Selecting techniques, methods, languages, architectures, taking into account their inherent limitations and the fact that information on concrete solutions is usually commercially coloured. Making strategic decisions in this respect: e.g. how do we protect our network? What type of database? What role for formal specifications? Scientific motivation of the decisions that have been made.

6. Reporting the progress and status of computer science projects to clients (meaning non-information scientists) and experts from other fields, both orally and in writing.

7. Leading a team of information scientists, including (a) assessment of the necessary means (time, budget, instruments, manpower, competences), (b) division of tasks on the basis of technical competences, (c) time planning of the tasks, (d) following and adjusting the planning.

8. Society. Has a sense of responsibility. Makes connections between social trends and developments in computer science and considers the consequences of actions.

9. Profundity. Has theoretical and practical experiences with instruments, techniques and methods used in scientific research of a specific subfield of information sciences.

10. Research and development in a product-oriented environment. This means (a) being able to set up experiments to determine if certain techniques are usable for a company; (b) recognising opportunities to improve products and production processes; (c) estimate costs/benefits of new techniques and methods; (d) using new techniques to gain a strategic advantage over the competition.

11. Fundamental research. Have the necessary skills needed to independently start scientific research, for instance in order to obtain a PhD. This means (a) having insight in current research questions within a subfield of Information Sciences; (b) being able to see the implications of recent research results; (c) being able to independently apply publicised results or techniques in a new context.

12. Protocol design. Designs algorithms and protocols fo optimal use in contemporary systems (wireless networks, cloud computing, …). Analyzes and optimizes such algorithms ans protocols depending on the context in which they are to be used.

13. Modelling and simulation. Studies the behaviour of contemporary systems (performance, robustness, scalability, ...) using models and simulations.

14. Mathematical modelling. Assesses if a certain mathematical model is suitable in a given situation. Quickly makes (small) adjustments to, or a variant of an existent model. Abstracts and models simple problems and gains necessary insights from the obtained results.

pages.title: Quality, facts and figures | Master of Computer Science: Computer Networks | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
At the University of Antwerp we ensure the quality of our programmes. Every programme goes through a six-year quality assurance cycle.

In year three, we review the quality assurance of the programme during the internal process monitoring and control. In autumn 2019 this was done for the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science.

A peer review in year six concludes the cycle. The study programme conducts a self-reflection and has  discussions with internal and external experts and with an independent student.

On 13-14 December 2023 the peer review team visited the bachelor and master in de informatica and the Master of Computer Science and decided to confirm its confidence in the programme.

Conclusions of the peer review team

The programme offers broad and well-balanced fundamentals in the bachelor's to be well prepared for the three specialisations in the master's, where the programme is strong in terms of research. Frequent use is made of group work and project work, where independent thinking and problem-solving is learned step by step. The programme plans more effective use of peer feedback and peer evaluation according to needs. The review team found that students (and graduates) are very satisfied with the programme since there are short lines of communication with teachers, concerns of students are taken into account and the developed hard and soft skills are a good preparation for the professional field.

To better match the large influx of Belgian and international students, in the coming period the programme will, among other things, make the structure of the programme and its unique profile clearer in communication. Possible obstacles to mapping out one's own path in the wide range of choices in the master's programme will be investigated and, if possible, remedied.

In order to get better acquainted with companies, job events will be organised and the possibility of a company internship will be looked into. More opportunities for international experiences will also be pursued.

​Read the entire public report​

Facts and figures

The website 'opleiding in cijfers' gives you more detailed information about alle programmes in Flemish university colleges and universities.

pages.title: Admission requirements | Master of Computer Science: Computer Networks | University of Antwerp
pages.html_content:
If you have a bachelor degree from the Benelux

Direct admission:

  • academic bachelor of Information Sciences
  • academic bachelor of Computer Science
  • academic bachelor of Engineering Sciences: Computer Science

If you have a bachelor degree from outside the Benelux

There are several criteria applicants with an international previous education must meet: academic requirements, programme specific requirements and English-language proficiency requirements.

1.      Academic admission requirements

You can apply for our master's programme if your bachelor's degree is deemed comparable to the University of Antwerp's bachelor's degree in Computer Science.  If you have a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science or Artificial Intelligence, or in a Computer Science-related programme from a foreign university with a level similar to Belgian universities, you are eligible to apply.

2.      Programme specific admission requirements

The Admission Board will also the assess whether your degree and background are sufficiently related to the level and content of our own BSc degree in Computer Science. 

Given the wide variety of computer science and informatics degrees, the Board of Admissions checks in particular:

  • Software engineering background: is the candidate familiar with object-oriented software development? Does the program include software-engineering courses with a significant software development component? Will the candidate be able to independently program software? Programs in which computer science was studied as a minor often lack in this respect.
  • Is there a solid mathematics background? Does the curriculum include advanced courses on discrete mathematics, linear algebra, calculus, and statistics? Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more application-oriented studies.
  • Does the curriculum cover theoretical computer science subjects? This includes the study of data structures, algorithm analysis, and computational complexity. Coverage of these topics is often an issue in more IT management, Informatics-like or Electrical Engineering-oriented bachelor’s programs.

How to demonstrate that you meet the programme specific requirements

You are required to indicate how you meet these programme specific admission requirements through our prescreening form.

This prescreening form is an essential element in this assessment, for the Board of Admissions and for yourself. Make sure to complete it rigorously and honestly. Based on your transcripts and the pre-screening form, the Board of Admissions checks if there is a good match of the topics covered by your Bachelor's program and our Bachelor's in Computer Science. The subjects are grouped into "Computer skills", "math skills", "theoretical computer science", "databases", "software engineering", and "computer networks". The board’s flexibility on which of these groups are not covered by courses you have taken is very limited. Also, self-study is only taken into account as reinforcement in a group where insufficiently many courses are listed, not as a replacement.

3.      Language requirements

The programme is taught in English and an academic level of proficiency in this language is imperative.

Candidates with a bachelor degree from universities outside Flanders are required to demonstrate their English language skills in by submitting one of the language certificates listed here.

You are required to indicate how you meet these programme specific admission requirements through our prescreening form.

This prescreening form is an essential element in this assessment, for the Board of Admissions and for yourself. Make sure to complete it rigorously and honestly. Based on your transcripts and the pre-screening form, the Board of Admissions checks if there is a good match of the topics covered by your Bachelor's program and our Bachelor's in Computer Science. The subjects are grouped into "Computer skills", "math skills", "theoretical computer science", "databases", "software engineering", and "computer networks". The board’s flexibility on which of these groups are not covered by courses you have taken is very limited. Also, self-study is only taken into account as reinforcement in a group where insufficiently many courses are listed, not as a replacement.

3.      Language requirements

The programme is taught in English and an academic level of proficiency in this language is imperative.

Candidates with a bachelor degree from universities outside Flanders are required to demonstrate their English language skills in by submitting one of the language certificates listed [here](https://www.uantwerpen.be/en/study/admission-and-enrolment/admission/master-and-advanced-master/admission-requirements/).

pages.html_content:
Bachelor's degree from the Benelux and you do not have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you don’t need to proceed via Mobility Online.

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that does not grant direct admission AND you are not required to have a visa, you will have to apply for permission from the faculty. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree from the Benelux but you have to apply for a visa?

If you have a bachelor's degree from a higher education institution IN Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg that grants direct admission BUT you are required to have a visa, you have to submit an online application via Mobility Online. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines. 

Bachelor's degree outside Benelux?

If you obtained a bachelor's or master's degree from a higher education institution OUTSIDE Belgium, the Netherlands or Luxembourg, you need to submit an online application via Mobility Online, before you can enrol. Pay attention to the deadlines!

You can submit your application, even if you do not yet meet all the requirements, providing you expect to do so before the applicable deadlines.
